vague_description: How can we determine the maximum radius of a ball centered within a specified region, such that the entire ball remains inside the region?
detailed_description:
PROBLEM TYPE
LP

INPUT FORMAT 

{
    "A": [[a_i_j for j in 1, ..., N] for i in 1, ..., M],
    "b": [b_i for i in 1, ..., M]
}

OBJECTIVE
We are interested in finding a ball with the largest possible radius, which is entirely contained within the set \param{P} (The center of such a ball is called the Chebychev center of \param{P}).
target_objective: Maximize the radius r of the ball centered at the Chebychev center that lies entirely within P
target_constraints: The radii of balls are non-negative
The ball must be completely within the set P, which is defined by the constraints Ax ≤ b
target_parameters: The number of inequalities defining the set P
The ambient space dimension of the set P
The coefficients of the linear inequalities defining the set P
The right-hand side of the inequalities defining the set P

Expert: Does the problem involve maximizing the radius of the inscribed ball while maintaining the center within a specified point or region?
User: Yes, the problem involves finding the Chebyshev center of a convex polyhedron, which is the center of the largest ball that can be inscribed in the region defined by the linear inequalities "Ax ≤ b". Generally, we solve for the Chebyshev center using a linear programming method which involves an additional slack variable representing the ball's radius.
